I would not recommend it for lunch, unless you enjoy greasy, deep fried foods.  The stations are broken down by type of cuisine, but it's kind of a disappoint. Nacho station had no cheese or guacamole, but the cheap fare e.g. beans. 

Breakfast had a wide selection of various things other people noted.  Their OJ was not watered down and gross, but actually palatable but they weren't as attentive with refilling the morning I came.  Staff was friendly and helpful, replacing my silverware when I came for breakfast, but not when I was there for lunch.  They allowed us to choose between booth or table, which was nice.

LIKE
- cheese blintz
- country fried steak with gravy
- churro (because there is no wrong time for churros, even though it was on the dry side, still good comparable to the rest of the fare)
- tiny sprinkled donuts (they had the bigger ones too, but oddly, with less sprinkles which is a waste of carbs because the whole point of getting the donut is for its sprinkles!)

PASS
- waffles (not crispy, soggy even though they were in cute heart shapes)
- eggs benedict (cold and flavorless)

Pancakes were basic, syrup was meh (didn't think you could mess up on syrup). They had the usual breakfast fare e.g oatmeal, grits, yogurt, dried fruit (raisins, cranberries, banana chips, etc.) 

You save a couple of bucks with the player's card, so for the 5 minutes it takes to sign up at the window by the front desk, it's worth the extra couple of feet in walking to work up your appetite, lol.  Plus is that it's conveniently located by the elevator so if you're not wanting to go far, St. Tropez is perfect.

I live in Las Vegas and have been to numerous buffets but this was my first trip to Suncoast for their buffet ( and my last) . I had a buy one get one free coupon but realized it doesn't start until August 1, but decided to give it a try for a locals $8.88 deal. I brought my mother and 15 year old niece with me. Cashier charges us $8.88 for me and my mom and my niece was charged $13.99 because there is no discount for anyone under 21. So $34 for 3 of us , not bad , or so I thought.
My first impression when I walked up to the small buffet area was oh no this whole buffet looks awful. We tried pizza which was horrible and had a very funny taste that I can't even pinpoint . I also tried pesto pasta and took 2 bites and left that on the plate . Dried almost to the point of been rock hard. The taste was horrible and the oil was just seeping from the pasta. Plate 3, I figured I could have salad. The salad area was very small but was the only fresh food item in the whole buffet. I have romaine lettuce was crisp and I topped with small carrots and onion . The ranch dressing was thin and watery but edible. 
These 3 items are the only ones I tried as everything else looked absolutely disgusting. My mom tried to eat a pork chop but could not because if was so hard you could t even cut it.
My recommendation is to never eat here. Seriously the worst food I have ever saw or sampled . I would never eat here again even if it was free. We almost got up 5 minutes after we ate and left but have decided the salad would hold us over until we ate later. 
Worst food and buffet I have ever gone to. Ugh

We had a brunch on the Sunday after our wedding at this buffet. It was amazing! The wait staff were very attentive and Deborah Valenti was great at helping us coordinate 100 people eating at the buffet in a private room. And, the food was great! All of our guests had nothing but positive things to say!

For the record, I don't like buffets.  Also for the record, the decor and ambiance of St. Tropez has seen better days.  The paucity of diners on the night we went probably has a clue to why the Suncoast isn't spending any money to spiff up the joint.

So why did we go?  It's Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year and, like the other locals' casinos, they had their Jewish Pigout (pun intended) up and running.  That is, gefilte fish, chopped liver, whitefish salad, boiled chicken (I passed - yuk), brisket, potato knishes, potato latkes, matzo ball soup, tsimmes (a sweet potato and carrot concoction), noodle pudding.  Though I'm not a fan of this Eastern European peasant food (even though I grew up with it, including the boiled chicken), my husband is, and he wanted to go.  Who am I to deny him his thrice-per-year Old World extravaganza?

Truth is, the food was suprisingly excellent, despite the dreary surroundings.  So was most everything else I tried, though I didn't try a lot except more veggies.  The desserts were unremarkable, except they've jumped on the gelato bandwagon, so what more does one need?

For 12.99, including free wine and beer, you can't cook this kind of meal for the price.  The wine and beer thing is confusing, though.  We didn't realize until halfway through the meal that it was included, since the sign at the register proclaims that a glass of wine is $3.00.  I still don't understand it.

Dinner here turned out to be a nice surprise.  Next week we'll try the holiday one at Red Rock, and see how it compares.  It's a dollar more, wines aren't included, but the atmosphere is a lot nicer.  We'll see if it measures up.

This place is a great deal, if you're after very simple, comfort-foods. We were seated very quickly,  everything was served at the proper temperature and the staff were friendly.

Be sure you bring/get your B-connected card, for the best pricing.

People, people, people.... Enough with the one star ratings already! 99.99% of you (including me) come here because we got 2 free buffet passes in the mail. Free food is free food people. You get what you pay for and in most of our cases, a belly full of free marginal food. If you paid full price for this place then you have a right to complain (but not much since it only cost you $9.99). Sucka!



We got here at 7PM and a good amount of the food looked like it had seen better days. 

Here is the good bad and the ugly...

The Good:
Knowing well in advance to temper my expectations I went for the high ticket item of the buffet; Prime Rib. The first round the roast looked dismal and looked sun burnt from being under the heat lamp for the past 2 hours. After eating my first slice of prime jerky got up and waited for the carver to pull a new roast out of the heater. At that point pretended to be a shark circling the buffet waiting for him to break into the new roast. It was well worth the wait 3 thin slices of rare prime rib... That right there was worth my gas in my car to drive to Suncoast.  

The salad bar believe it or not was stocked with GREEN lettuce and fresh veggies!

Pizza seemed to be a hot ticket item. Every trip up the the station there was a fresh pie waiting for me. 


The Bad & Ugly:

The guacamole and wasabi both were brown and looked like it had developed a hard candy shell. Although I have a rock gut I decided not to tempt fate and eat my tacos w/o the green stuff. 

The chili cheese fries looked and tasted like they tried to reincarnate last nights baked potatoes by cutting them into wedges and throwing chili on them.. Bleh!

The pasta and and ravioli looked sad and dismal. all the dishes looked like they were set out during the lunch buffet. Not even a dent in any one of them.



The food (some of it) is edible you just have to use your sound judgement and pick wisely. 

In summary people, there is not much room to complain when we are all eating here for free or heavily discounted. So temper your expectations and be thankful for the free prime rib. 

That is all....

OK this place takes disgusting to a new level!  It looks nice for a cheap buffet but the food was so disgusting I could not even find one thing to eat.  Everything in this place tasted like it was hospital food at a geriatric ward everything  sitting on the steamtables was old and had been sitting there all day.  For about the same price as one of the stations casinos buffets take the drive and go over there.  I can always find one thing to eat at a buffet but this place there was literally nothing just gross.  I wouldn't feed that garbage to a starving dog!  However if you're stuck at the Suncoast like I was go to the coffee shop it's a little better.

The Mongolian BBQ station is delicious and the chef is very polite. The mashed potato gravy is the most delicious in town. The servers are very well trained and friendly. My family and I enjoy eating there every weekend!
